title: What â€œHold My Beerâ€ Really Means & How to Use It

steps.title: â€œHold my beerâ€ means someone wants to top or one-up someone else.
steps.content: â€œHold my beerâ€ means someone wants to top or one-up someone else. Itâ€™s like saying, â€œI could do that! Hold my beer while I demonstrate!â€ Usually, the activity in question is something ridiculous or comical, like parkouring over a bench, but it could be something more tame too, like acing a test. The phrase is meant to be lighthearted and joking. â€œI can do a backflip too! Hold my beer!â€ â€œA hot dog eating contest? Hold my beer.â€ â€œHold my beerâ€ can also be abbreviated as HMB.

steps.title: People say â€œHold my beerâ€ while they joke about doing something risky or ill-advised.

Hold my beer, Iâ€™m gonna go watch.â€ â€œI bet I can make that jump. steps.title: â€œHold my beerâ€ also shows an eagerness or complete lack of hesitation to do something.
steps.content: â€œHold my beerâ€ also shows an eagerness or complete lack of hesitation to do something. steps.title: People also use â€œHold my beerâ€ to jokingly compare two notable or public fails.
steps.content: People also use â€œHold my beerâ€ to jokingly compare two notable or public fails. Hold my beer is also commonly used as a meme to make fun of when a celebrity, brand, or random person online makes an even bigger mistake than one of their peers, or when they manage to do something better. Itâ€™s like theyâ€™re saying, â€œHold my beer, I can do something worse/better than them.â€ [2] X Research source Tesla: â€œWe ruined our brand loyalty in just 2 months.â€ Southwest Airlines: â€œHold my beer.â€ TikToker: â€œI just manifested the most amazing relationship!â€ Someone making a stitch: â€œHold my beer! steps.title: â€œHold my beerâ€ appeared in the mid-1990s by comedian Jeff Foxworthy.
steps.content: â€œHold my beerâ€ appeared in the mid-1990s by comedian Jeff Foxworthy. Back in the mid-1990s, Southern comedian Jeff Foxworthy had a joke formula that poked fun at the â€œredneckâ€ life he was exposed to. It went, â€œYou might be a redneck if your last words before losing consciousness have ever been, â€œHey, yâ€™all, watch this!â€ before doing something dangerous. This eventually inspired the phrase we know and love so well: â€œHold my beer and watch this!â€ [3] X Research source

steps.title: â€œHold my beerâ€ gained popularity on X (formerly Twitter) in 2016.
steps.content: â€œHold my beerâ€ gained popularity on X (formerly Twitter) in 2016. After the 2016 United States presidential election, â€œHMBâ€ became a trending phrase on Twitter. It was a way for people to laugh during dark times. Users used the phrase to highlight the poor decisions of politicians, celebrities, and brands against one another to make an ironic joke. [4] X Research source A popular example is the United States asking a post-Brexit United Kingdom to hold its beer before electing Donald Trump as president. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Use â€œHold my beerâ€ when you want to one-up someone or something.
steps.content: Use â€œHold my beerâ€ when you want to one-up someone or something. Confident you can do better? Even if thereâ€™s no way you can compete (you probably canâ€™t outrun an Olympian), it can still make a great joke! In most cases, folks will assume youâ€™re crackinâ€™ a joke in the first place. If youâ€™re retweeting or stitching with someone online, include a photo or video of your one-up as proof! Them: â€œMy burger recipe is the best there is.â€ You: â€œOh yeah? Hold my beer!â€ Them: â€œI have the cutest dog!â€ You: â€œHold my beer and LOOK AT THIS GOOD BOY! ğŸ¶â€

steps.title: Say â€œHold my beerâ€ as a joke about doing something risky.
steps.content: Say â€œHold my beerâ€ as a joke about doing something risky. Have you ever gotten the sudden urge to do something completely ridiculous? While you shouldnâ€™t actually go through with something that could hurt or embarrass you, itâ€™s fun to pretend! Them: â€œBet you canâ€™t ride that bike without handlebars.â€ You: â€œHold my beer!â€ â€œIâ€™ll show those Alaskan fishermen how itâ€™s done. Hold my beer!â€ Keep in mind that these are hypothetical or humorous situations. Have a real â€œhold my beerâ€ moment at your own risk!

steps.content: Show how eager you are to do something with â€œHold my beer.â€ If you canâ€™t wait to get at something, yell or post â€œHold my beer!â€ to show the world youâ€™re raring to go. â€œHold my beerâ€ goes with everything, from wanting to do something real (like asking out a crush) or something comical or exaggerated (like launching yourself into outer space). Hold my beer!â€ Them: â€œSpaceX just launched a new rocket.â€ You: â€œOh please, Iâ€™ve got a bottle rocket in the backyard. Hold my beer, Elon!â€

steps.title: Tweet or meme â€œHold my beerâ€ to call out major events or public figures as flops.
steps.content: Tweet or meme â€œHold my beerâ€ to call out major events or public figures as flops. Have you ever skimmed a news headline and said, â€œHuh?â€ In situations where major events seem contradictory or two celebs or politicians almost seem like theyâ€™re competing to fail harder, you could highlight this in an â€œHMBâ€ tweet. The format works best as two lines of dialogue between people, brands, or organizations where one does something â€œdumberâ€ than the other. For example, if one brand sells a product with a defect and then one of their competitors makes an even bigger error, you could format the joke like: Brand 1: â€œWeâ€™re gonna charge you a fortune for a product that doesnâ€™t work!â€ Brand 2: â€œHold my beer.â€

steps.title: Comment â€œHMBâ€ on a fail video.
steps.content: Comment â€œHMBâ€ on a fail video. As you scroll through TikToks and shorts, itâ€™s only a matter of time before you end up on the corner of the internet that highlights peopleâ€™s painfully embarrassing fails. Letâ€™s be real, thoughâ€”itâ€™s hard not to laugh! Thatâ€™s the perfect time to leave an â€œHMBâ€ comment and get plenty of likes in return. [6] X Research source Fail videos depict someoneâ€™s mistakes, shortcomings, or unfortunate outcomes. Leave a â€œhold my beerâ€ comment on a video of something like a person failing to hop over a fire pit with a dirt bike.

steps.title: The HMB meme features pics or GIFs of epic fails with the caption â€œHold my beer.â€
steps.content: The HMB meme features pics or GIFs of epic fails with the caption â€œHold my beer.â€ In 2013, the Twitter (X) account @HoldMyBeerGif launched and shared photos, videos, and GIFs of epic fail moments (picture skateboard tricks gone wrong, painful belly flops from a big height, or anything that makes you go â€œOuch! Thatâ€™s gotta hurt.â€). The caption â€œHold my beerâ€ implies that the person in the video saw someone do the stunt successfully, then tried (and failed) to imitate it. [7] X Research source Currently, the @HoldMyBeerGif account is suspended on X (formerly Twitter). May the memes live on!

steps.title: GOAT
steps.content: GOAT GOAT is a popular term amongst Gen Zers that means the Greatest of All Time. It describes someone who has performed better than anyone else. Itâ€™s most commonly associated with sports, specifically the boxer Mohammad Ali, known as â€œThe Greatest.â€ [9] X Research source â€œMr. G didnâ€™t give us homework again. steps.title: Yeet
steps.content: Yeet Yeeting something means to throw or chuck something really far and really hard with some enthusiasm or flair. A viral Vine of a student throwing an empty soda can with force put this term on the map. As it evolved, it also came to be an expression for surprise or enthusiasm. [10] X Research source â€œMy cat yeets himself into the air whenever he sees a cucumber ğŸ˜†â€ Person 1: â€œWanna grab drinks tonight?â€ Person 2: â€œYeet letâ€™s do it!â€
